docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Linda Klein and David Andrew Mannis were married on Wednesday at the State Court of Claims in New York. Judge Albert A. Blinder, a retired judge of that court, officiated. Ms. Klein, 43, is keeping her name. She is a vice president in New York with the management communications group of Fleishman Hillard, a public relations company. She graduated from Skidmore College. She is a daughter of Eleanore and Leslie E. Klein of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: States are using less than 20 percent of the Federal money that Congress made available, with much fanfare, for a big new program to subsidize health insurance for children in low-income families. Some states say they cannot find enough eligible uninsured children to use all the money they are entitled to receive. Critics say many states have been slow to reach out to eligible children and sign them up.

headline.main: Many States Slow to Use Children's Insurance Fund

docs.abstract: States are using less than 20 percent of Federal money Congress made available under 1997 Children's Health Insurance Program to subsidize health insurance for children in low-income families; some say they cannot find enough eligible uninsured children to use all money they are entitled to receive, while critics say they have been slow to reach out to eligible children to sign them up; program's slow start and accumulation of unspent money are tempting Republicans in Congress to take back some of money and use it for other purposes--idea vehemently opposed by Democrats, advocates for children and by governors of both parties; Congress provided $39 billion for program over $10 years, including $4.2 billion per year in 1998 and 1999; Federal officials say states used $260 million through December 1998 and $115 million through first three months of 1999; Congressional Budget Office estimates they will use total of $800 million in 1999 (M)
docs.snippet: States are using less than 20 percent of the Federal money that Congress made available, with much fanfare, for a big new program to subsidize health insurance for children in low-income families.    Some states say they cannot find enough eligible...

docs.lead_paragraph: Susan Faessler was recently helping her mother-in-law move into an apartment at an assisted-living center here, Heritage at Framingham, when her cell phone rang. ''It's Tom,'' Mrs. Faessler said, referring to her husband. ''He wants to know how you like it.'' ''Tell him I'm getting used to it,'' said her mother-in-law, 87-year-old Trudy Faessler.

headline.main: A HELPING HOME: A special report.; A Niche for the Elderly, and for the Market

docs.abstract: Assisted-living facilities are spreading across America and now provide housing and an array of services to about 1.2 million people; definition of assisted living varies widely from locale to locale among nation's 30,000 assisted-living centers, and there is great variation in services they provide and fees they charge; experts ask whether assisted living is real solution for new stage of life or marketing opportunity directed at the affluent elderly and their adult children; some critics ask what will happen to assisted-living residents who run out of money or grow more disabled; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Congress makes a mistake that inflicts undue hurt on individuals and their families, it has a duty to correct the injustice. Harsh deportation rules adopted in 1996 condemn many productive legal residents to automatic expulsion based on low-level offenses they committed long ago, and for which they have paid their debt to society. The problem arises because Congress failed to draw a distinction between immigrants who committed murder, rape and other serious crimes worthy of deportation and those who committed a minor theft or were found in possession of a small quantity of drugs. Hundreds of longtime legal residents with minor offenses have been abruptly wrenched from their families and sent back to their birth countries.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Congress has inflicted undue harm on individuals and families with its 1996 bill that calls for automatic expulsion of legal immigrants who commit even low-level offenses long ago and have since repaid debt to society; says time has come to correct injustice by passing bill sponsored by Reprs Barney Frank, Martin Frost and Lincoln Diaz-Balart to restore judicial discretion and due process rights

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Cuts in Medicare money are not the only reason teaching hospitals are suffering financially (news article, May 6).

headline.main: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift; Doctors of Tomorrow

docs.abstract: Dr Richard P Wenzel letter, commenting on May 6 article, disputes suggestion that cuts in Medicare money is main reason why teaching hospitals are suffering financially (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Cuts in Medicare money are not the only reason teaching hospitals are suffering financially (news article, May 6).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A May 6 news article describing the adverse effects that cuts in Medicare reimbursement appear to be inflicting on teaching hospitals overlooks another ominous consequence of the declining financial state of these teaching hospitals: the loss of academic leadership. Chairmanships in academic medical departments used to be sought-after positions that gave doctors resources to build strong clinical and innovative research programs. The current job of chairman is to receive bad news from the dean and to transmit it to the faculty. As a result, chairmanships are no longer viewed as desirable positions. In fact, about a quarter of the surgical chairmanships in the United States are vacant. TIMOTHY G. BUCHMAN, M.D. St. Louis, May 6, 1999 The writer is a professor of surgery, Washington University School of Medicine.

headline.main: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift; As Leaders Disappear

docs.abstract: Letter from Prof Timothy G Buchman (Washington University School of Medicine), commenting on May 6 article, says it overlooked another ominous consequence of declining financial state of teaching hospitals, namely, loss of academic leadership; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: RECALLING the opening of Bloomingdale's in New Rochelle more than 50 years ago, Robert J. Streger, president of the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce, said: ''It was a big event. My mother and her friends were thrilled. Bloomingdale's had come to Westchester. Now they wouldn't have to go to the city to shop anymore.'' Mr. Streger, head of Israel Streger, an insurance company founded by his father, continued: ''Bloomingdale's took over the very old Ware's Department Store on Main Street. The store was instantly a big draw and the magnet that drew people to New Rochelle. Main Street blossomed. Stores and restaurants thrived. It was a terrific time for the city, but in 1975 Bloomingdale's built a large, very modern store in White Plains, and in 1976, the New Rochelle store was closed, and Main Street slipped into a decline.''

headline.main: A Face Lift for Bloomingdale's in White Plains

docs.lead_paragraph: TWINS, these days, seem to be everywhere. Although septuplets and octuplets have attracted national attention lately, statistics show that twin births are up 47 percent nationwide from 1980 to 1996. High-order multiples (triplets or more) are extremely rare. In most multiple births, the babies come in twos, but, even then, carrying them to term isn't always easy.

headline.main: Hands, and Hearts, Filled With Twins

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER a run of profitable years, hospitals across the country face cash-flow problems -- squeezed, officials say, by slow-paying managed-care companies, cutbacks in government programs and rapidly growing numbers of uninsured patients. Pressured by rising costs, hospitals are aggressively trying to collect mountains of overdue bills for patient care. According to the hospitals, managed-care companies are routinely delaying payments by three or four months, even in states where delays that long are illegal, often by reporting that they have lost track of bills, including those transmitted electronically.

headline.main: Insurers and Uninsured Put Hospitals in a Squeeze

docs.snippet: AFTER a run of profitable years, hospitals across the country face cash-flow problems -- squeezed, officials say, by slow-paying managed-care companies, cutbacks in government programs and rapidly growing numbers of uninsured patients. Pressured by...

docs.lead_paragraph: For Dr. Marilyn Gordon, it would be unthinkable that Cooper Hospital would turn away patients who can't pay their bills. ''This is a city that needs a lot of medical attention,'' said Dr. Gordon, a hospital internist who was born at Cooper and raised in its shadow. ''My practice is based on a lot of people I've grown up with and, as long as I can remember, Cooper has always supported the Camden community and the community has always supported it.''

headline.main: In Camden, A Hospital Finds Itself Seriously Ill
